data.text: @TheSecretSarah A whole thread on catching a cold 😆
@TheSecretSarah Thank goodness I've become impervious to the fearmongering.

Yes, you can have people acting irresponsibly on a negative test, but we are in a new phase of the pandemic. People are returning to normal anyway. If they know they are positive they’re more likely to be cautious.

Due to the nature of their work they had access to a rapid test and could then take precautions. I had access to rapid tests so, same. At home rapid tests, cheap, available & sponsored where possible, are really a tool we should be using more than PCR. PCR is expensive.

They felt terrible & kept apologizing. When you don’t have symptoms you don’t think you’re infected (why masks & ventilation are important). My dad has all the comorbidities so while I kept repeating, it’s not your fault, I was grateful they told me.

...& SARS-CoV2 is an infectious virus. Stigma could have made the other person not tell me their result. It isn’t their fault, *it’s an infectious virus*. There are things we all can do, personal steps. Luckily their symptoms resolved next day (they’re older so I was worried).

I was staying with a family member with a baby, so was grateful I was told about the other persons positive test (22-2). A step I am grateful they took. I wore a n95 that night & went home (23-2) & have been careful around family. Why am I telling you this: We are all human!

Both of us are vac’d. The next day (22-2) they woke up with symptoms & tested. Dark rapid test positive & low ct on PCR. I know this translates to likely at most infectious when I was with them & that there are steps I could take to not transmit (few ppl have these options).

I know we don’t legally have to quarantine as contacts. However, I feel my exposure (21-2) was a risk. I felt sure I would test positive. I was in a shared space for a few hrs. It wasn’t a situation much in my control. I could make that choice so I did.
